Top 5 Time Management Tips for CAT Aspirants

{/*

ðŸ‘¤ Tathagat Faculty

*/}

ðŸ•’ April 26, 2025

Introduction:

Managing time during preparation â€” and during the exam itself â€” can make or break your CAT score. Itâ€™s not just about how much you know; itâ€™s about how efficiently you apply that knowledge under pressure. Many bright students lose marks not because they didnâ€™t know the answer, but because they spent too much time on tough questions, panicked under time pressure, or couldnâ€™t plan their preparation well. The good news? Time management is a skill you can learn and master â€” with the right approach and consistent practice.

Here are five proven strategies straight from CAT toppers and Tathagat mentors that can help you maximize every minute.

1. Prioritize High-Impact Topics

Not all topics are created equal. Some areas consistently carry more weight in the exam â€” mastering these gives you a better return on your time investment.
âœ” Identify the most important topics based on past CAT papers (e.g., Arithmetic, Algebra in Quant; Reading Comprehension in Verbal).
âœ” Devote more time to mastering these before moving to less-weighted areas.
Tip:
Create a simple checklist and update it weekly to track your command over high-impact topics.

2. Train Early with Full-Length Mocks

Mocks are your best friends.
âœ” Start taking full-length mock tests early â€” ideally 3â€“4 months before the exam.
âœ” Analyze your performance: look beyond scores; check where you spent too much time, where you guessed, and where you skipped.
Important:
Mock tests should simulate real exam conditions â€” same time slots, same environment, and no distractions.

3. Master the Art of Skipping

Time management inside the exam hall is all about smart decision-making.
âœ” Donâ€™t get emotionally attached to questions.
âœ” If a question looks lengthy, tricky, or confusing in the first few seconds, skip it and move on.
âœ” Come back later if time permits â€” after all, CAT rewards accuracy, not ego!
Remember:
Sometimes, not attempting a tough question is a winning move.

{/*

Don't Just Dream It. Crack It
with Tathagat!

*/}
{/* Left Box */}

Join Our Telegram Channel

Get instant updates on exam strategies, free study materials, daily quizzes, important deadlines, and direct mentor tips â€” all in one place.

âœ… Exclusive Resources âœ… Doubt-Solving With Mentors âœ… GK & Current Affairs Updates âœ… Peer Discussions And Motivation

Be part of the TathaGat learning community!

{/* Right Box */}

Join our Free Telegram
Discussion Group!

4. Study in Small, Intense Bursts

Long study hours without focus can drain your energy without real progress.
âœ” Instead, use techniques like Pomodoro (25 minutes focused study + 5 minutes break).
âœ” Break your day into 2â€“3 focused sessions â€” Quant in the morning, Verbal and LRDI in the evening.
Example Routine:
â€¢ 8 AM â€“ 10 AM: Quantitative Aptitude practice
â€¢ 5 PM â€“ 6:30 PM: Verbal Ability practice
â€¢ 9 PM â€“ 10 PM: Mock Analysis

5. Build Exam-Day Endurance

CAT is a 2-hour mental marathon. You must train your brain for sustained focus.
âœ” Practice sitting for long periods without distractions.
âœ” Take back-to-back mocks closer to the exam day to build stamina.
Pro Tip:
Simulate the emotional pressure too â€” treat mocks seriously so you get used to performing under stress.

Conclusion

Time management isnâ€™t a trick you pull out on exam day â€” itâ€™s a habit you build over months of smart preparation.
Start applying these strategies now. Break your studies into achievable goals. Practice under pressure. Stay consistent.
By exam day, time will no longer be your enemy â€” it will be your secret weapon.

CAT
2024
IIM
TATHAGAT

COMMON ADMISSION TEST

Mock Test Instructions

{/* Main Content Container */}
{/* Left Panel - Instructions */}

INSTRUCTIONS

General Instructions:

  1. The number, type and pattern of questions, as well as sequence and timing of sections in the Mock Exam are only indicative and these are subject to variations from year to year as decided by the CAT Committee.
  2. The time allowed to each section is {testDetails.sections?.[0]?.duration || 60} minutes and 20 seconds for each candidates and 20 seconds for PWD candidates) as soon as you start answering a section, the clock displayed on the top right corner of the screen will start. On expiry of allotted time, the clock will indicate the auto-submission. You will then need to move to the next section and start answering the next set of questions. The same process can be repeated for the other two sections. A summary of your answers will be displayed on your screen.
  3. Each candidate will be provided at the beginning of the Mock Exam with an instruction sheet. The sheet will contain, among other things, details of the section-wise distribution of questions, marking scheme, time allotted for answering the questions in each section, instructions for submitting the answers of a section before moving to the next section.
  4. You will be allowed to leave the test hall only after a maximum of {testDetails.duration} minutes.
  5. Your time will be up and synchronized automatically upon the completion of the exam at the last section of your screen and display the results instantly. When all the candidates finish in your screening venue, you will be directed to complete the survey, which may be used for research purposes.
  6. PWD candidates will be allocated {testDetails.duration + 20} minutes and 20 seconds for each section and {testDetails.duration + 60} minutes and 20 seconds by clicking on the Submit button. After 20 minutes and 20 seconds. However, the clock will be section-wise automatically end.
  7. The question paper will have a mix of multiple choice questions (MCQ) type with options and Non-MCQ type.
  8. A writing pad will be provided to the candidates for rough work, which will have to be returned after the test. Please note that only one writing pad will be provided to you. Candidates should check with their allotted centre if they require additional number on the writing pad.
  9. The items/materials that are allowed to be used for computation: You will not be allowed to use any electronic, computing instrument, or device.
  10. The question palette displayed on the right side of the screen will show the status of each question with the help of one of the following symbols:
1
Question Number on right side is Missing
A
You have not visited the question yet.
B
You have visited the question but not answered it.
C
You have answered the question but have marked it as Marked for Review.
D
You have answered the question but have not marked it as Marked for Review.
5*
You have answered the question as well as marked it as Marked for Review.

Answers to all questions flagged as 'Marked for Review' (Some No.) will not be automatically considered as submitted for evaluation at the end of the time allotted for that section.

10. You can click on the arrow which appears to the right of the question palette to collapse the question palette in case you want to view the entire screen space. To view the question palette again, you can click on the arrow which appears on the right side of the computer console. Please note that you may have to scroll down to view the full question and options in some cases.

To answer a question, you will have to do the following:

  1. Click on the question number in the Question palette to go to that question directly.
  2. Select an answer for an MCQ by clicking on the radio button placed just before the choice.

For a Non-MCQ, enter only a whole number as the answer in the space provided on the screen using the on-screen keyboard. For example, if the correct answer is a Non-MCQ is 50, then enter ONLY 50 and NOT 50.0 or 50.00.

  1. Click on Save & Next to save your answer for the current question and then go to the next question.

Alternatively, you may click on Mark for Review & Next to save your answer for the current question and mark it for review, and then move to the next question.

Caution: Your answer for the current question will not be saved, if you navigate directly to another question by clicking on a question number and not click Save & Next or Mark for Review & Next button.

const mongoose = require("mongoose");

const iimPredictorSchema = new mongoose.Schema({
    userId: {
        type: mongoose.Schema.Types.ObjectId,
        ref: "User", // Link this data to the User Model
        required: true,
    },
    category: { type: String, required: true },
    gender: { type: String, required: true },
    classX: { type: Number, required: true },
    classXII: { type: Number, required: true },
    discipline: { type: String, required: true },
    graduation: { type: String, required: true },
    gradPercentage: { type: Number, required: true },
    workExperience: { type: Number, required: true },
    takenCATBefore: { type: String, required: true },
    catYear: { type: Number, required: true },
    interestedCourses: { type: [String], required: true }, // Store selected courses as an array

    // âœ… New CMAT Score Prediction Fields
    qt: { type: Number, required: false, default: 0 }, // Quantitative Techniques
    lr: { type: Number, required: false, default: 0 }, // Logical Reasoning
    lc: { type: Number, required: false, default: 0 }, // Language Comprehension
    ga: { type: Number, required: false, default: 0 }, // General Awareness
    totalScore: { type: Number, required: false, default: 0 }, // Automatically Calculated
    predictedPercentile: { type: Number, required: false, default: 0 }, // AI-based Predicted Percentile

}, { timestamps: true });

module.exports = mongoose.model("IIMPredictor", iimPredictorSchema);

Comprehensive Guide to the XAT Exam in India

The Xavier Aptitude Test (XAT) is one of Indiaâ€™s most prestigious entrance exams for admission to MBA/PGDM programs. It is conducted by the Xavier Labour Relations Institute (XLRI), Jamshedpur, and is accepted by several top business schools across the country. Below is a structured breakdown of all the essential details regarding the XAT exam.

1. Exam Details

The Xavier Aptitude Test (XAT) is an entrance exam conducted annually for admission to MBA and PGDM programs at XLRI and several other participating institutes. XAT is known for its rigorous structure and challenging questions, making it a crucial exam for MBA aspirants.

  • Conducting Body: Xavier Labour Relations Institute (XLRI), Jamshedpur
  • Mode of Examination: Computer-Based Test (CBT)
  • Duration: 3 hours (180 minutes)
  • Language: English
  • Type of Questions: Multiple Choice Questions (MCQs) and Subjective (Essay Writing)
  • Scoring System:
    • Each correct answer carries 1 mark.
    • There is a penalty of âˆ’0.25 marks for every incorrect answer.
    • Unattempted questions are not penalized.
    • Some sections may have a different marking scheme (e.g., the Essay section is typically not scored for ranking purposes but may be used in the final selection).

2. Eligibility Criteria

  • Educational Qualification: Candidates must have a Bachelor's degree in any discipline from a recognized university. Final-year students are also eligible to apply, provided they complete their degree before the commencement of the program.
  • Minimum Marks: No specific minimum percentage, but a recognized undergraduate degree is required.
  • Age Limit: No age limit.
  • Nationality: Both Indian Nationals and Foreign Nationals are eligible to apply. Foreign Nationals may have to fulfill additional requirements as per institution policy.

3. Exam Structure

The XAT exam is divided into two main sections, with the second part involving a subjective question:

  • Part 1: Objective Type Questions (MCQs)
    • Verbal and Logical Ability (VA & LR): RC, grammar, logical reasoning.
    • Decision Making (DM): Scenario-based decision skills.
    • Quantitative Ability and Data Interpretation (QA & DI): Math + DI sets.
  • Part 2:
    • General Knowledge (GK): Current affairs, business, general awareness.
    • Essay Writing: Writing skills & argumentation on a given topic.

4. Last Yearâ€™s Section-Wise Number of Questions

  • Verbal and Logical Ability (VA & LR): 26 questions
  • Decision Making (DM): 21 questions
  • Quantitative Ability and Data Interpretation (QA & DI): 28 questions
  • General Knowledge (GK): 25 questions
  • Essay Writing: 1 essay question (subjective; not scored for overall ranking but considered for final selection)
  • Total Number of Questions: 101 (MCQs + Essay Writing)

5. Syllabus

  • Verbal and Logical Ability (VA & LR): Reading Comprehension; Vocabulary (usage, synonyms, antonyms, idioms); English Grammar (sentence correction, error spotting, completion); Logical Reasoning (puzzles, seating, coding-decoding, data sufficiency).
  • Decision Making (DM): Ethical/moral dilemmas; decisions in business/society/personal contexts; problem-solving & judgment.
  • Quantitative Ability and Data Interpretation (QA & DI): Arithmetic (percentages, ratios, P&L, time & work); Algebra (equations, functions, inequalities); Geometry & Mensuration; DI (tables, graphs, charts, datasets).
  • General Knowledge (GK): Current Affairs; Business & Economy; History/Geography/Culture; Science & Technology.
  • Essay Writing: Social issues, contemporary business/management, or abstract topics; clarity, structure, logic.

6. Exam Date

The XAT exam is typically held in the first week of January each year. Expected XAT 2025 (subject to change):

  • Application Start Date: August
  • Application Deadline: November
  • Admit Card Release Date: December
  • Exam Date: First week of January
  • Result Declaration: January (usually in the third or fourth week)

Check the official XAT website for specific dates and schedule updates.

7. Selection Procedure

  1. XAT Exam: MCQs + Essay.
  2. Shortlisting for Further Rounds: Based on XAT score; next rounds typically include Group Discussion (GD) and/or Personal Interview (PI).
  3. Group Discussion (GD): Communication skills, personality, and current-affairs awareness.
  4. Personal Interview (PI): Interpersonal skills, confidence, academics, goals, and program fit.
  5. Final Selection: Composite of XAT score, GD/PI, past academics, work experience (if any), and institute criteria.

8. Colleges Accepting XAT Score

  • XLRI Jamshedpur â€” PGDM (Business Management), PGDM (Human Resource Management)
  • XIM University, Bhubaneswar â€” MBA (BM/HRM)
  • SPJIMR, Mumbai â€” Post Graduate Management Programs (shortlist via XAT)
  • IMT Ghaziabad â€” PGDM programs
  • FORE School of Management, New Delhi â€” PGDM programs
  • Goa Institute of Management (GIM), Goa
  • IMT Nagpur & Hyderabad
  • TAPMI, Manipal
  • XIMB (Xavier Institute of Management, Bhubaneswar)
  • Several other reputed institutes across India also accept XAT scores.

Conclusion

The XAT exam is a crucial exam for aspirants looking to pursue an MBA or PGDM from some of the most reputed institutes in India, especially XLRI Jamshedpur. With its rigorous exam structure, comprehensive syllabus, and a robust selection process, XAT remains one of the most competitive exams in India. Aspirants must focus on preparing well across all sections, including general knowledge and essay writing, to secure a high score and successfully navigate the admission process.

replit.md.content:
# Tathagat - CAT Exam Preparation Platform

## Overview
Full-stack educational platform for CAT (Common Admission Test) preparation with comprehensive course management, mock tests, live classes, and student progress tracking.

## Project Structure
- **Backend** (`backend1/`): Node.js/Express API server
  - Port: 5000 (backend API)
  - Database: MongoDB Atlas
  - Features: Course management, user authentication, mock tests, live classes, payment integration
  
- **Frontend** (`Frontend1/`): React application
  - Port: 5000 (production setup for Replit)
  - Features: Student dashboard, course viewer, mock test interface, admin panel

## Technology Stack
- **Backend**: Node.js, Express, MongoDB (Mongoose), JWT authentication
- **Frontend**: React, React Router, Axios, Chart.js
- **External Services**: Razorpay (payments), Zoom (live classes), Nodemailer (emails)

## Recent Changes
- Imported from GitHub (October 27, 2025)
- Configured for Replit environment
- Updated port configuration: Backend (3001), Frontend (5000)
- Enabled host check bypass for Replit proxy support
- Configured deployment settings for VM deployment

## Environment Setup
- **Backend**: Runs on localhost:3001
- **Frontend**: Runs on 0.0.0.0:5000 (public-facing)
- **Database**: MongoDB Atlas (pre-configured)
- **Development Mode**: Enabled with sample data seeding
- **Proxy**: Frontend proxies API requests to backend on port 3001

## Key Features
1. Student Dashboard with course progress tracking
2. Mock test and practice test system
3. Live class management with Zoom integration
4. Admin panel for course and content management
5. Discussion forum
6. Study materials management
7. IIM predictor tool
8. CRM for lead management

## Running the Project

### Development
The project uses a single workflow that runs both frontend and backend:
- Workflow: `Frontend` (runs `npm run dev:full` in Frontend1 directory)
- This starts both the React frontend (port 5000) and Express backend (port 3001)

### Environment Variables
- Backend environment variables are configured in `backend1/.env`
- MongoDB connection string is pre-configured
- JWT secret is set for authentication
- Email service (SMTP) is configured for notifications

### Important Notes
- The frontend uses `DANGEROUSLY_DISABLE_HOST_CHECK=true` to work with Replit's proxy
- Backend runs on localhost (not exposed publicly)
- Frontend proxies all `/api` requests to the backend on port 3001
- Sample data seeding is controlled by the `SKIP_SEED` environment variable

### Known Issues
- **React Compilation**: The frontend is a large React application that may take 2-3 minutes to compile on first start
- Memory optimizations have been added (`NODE_OPTIONS=--max-old-space-size=8192`, `GENERATE_SOURCEMAP=false`) 
- If the frontend fails to start, the workflow will automatically retry
- The backend API is fully functional and accessible at `http://localhost:3001/api`

### Deployment
- Configured for VM deployment (stateful application)
- Runs the same `dev:full` command that starts both services
- MongoDB Atlas is used for production database

MICA â€“ Strategic Marketing & Communications (PGDM-C)

{/* ðŸŽ¥ YouTube Embed */}

The Mudra Institute of Communications, Ahmedabad (MICA) is one of Indiaâ€™s top institutes for Strategic Marketing and Communication. Established in 1991, MICA has carved a niche with strong focus on marketing, brand management, media, and advertising. The flagship Post Graduate Diploma in Management â€“ Communications (PGDM-C) is designed to develop industry-ready professionals.

Program Overview

MICAâ€™s PGDM-C is a two-year, full-time residential program approved by AICTE. The curriculum blends creativity with strategic marketing, covering Brand Management, Digital Marketing, Media Management, Advertising, and Market Research.

Admission Process

  1. Entrance Exam: CAT / XAT / GMAT
  2. MICAT (MICA Admission Test): Conducted twice a year (Dec & Jan). Higher score of MICAT I or II is considered. Held across 48+ cities.
  3. Group Exercise (GE) & Personal Interview (PI): Shortlisted candidates are invited. Final selection = CAT/XAT/GMAT + MICAT + GE/PI.

Cut-off Trends

MICA does not officially declare cut-offs. However, past trends show that CAT/XAT percentile 80+ improves chances significantly.

Eligibility Criteria

import "./Instruction.css" import tableImage from '../../images/tablecontent.jpeg'; import { GoZoomIn } from "react-icons/go"; import { AiOutlineZoomOut } from "react-icons/ai"; const Instruction = () => { return (
Instructions Close âœ–
Note that the timer is ticking while you read the instructions. Close this page to return to answering the questions.

Instructions

General Instructions:

1. The number, type and pattern of questions, as well as sequence and timing of sections in the Mock Exam are only indicative and these are subject to variations from year to year as decided by the CAT authorities.

2. The test has 3 (three) sections. The total duration of the test is 120 minutes. PwD candidates will have 13 minutes and 20 seconds extra time for each section.

3. The time allotted to each section is 40 minutes (53 minutes and 20 seconds for PwD candidates)...

4. You will be allowed to leave the test hall only after a minimum of 120 minutes.

5. Your time will be set and synchronized... When the timer reaches zero, the test for that section will automatically end.

6. The question paper will have a mix of Multiple Choice Question (MCQ) type with options and Non-MCQ type.

7. A writing pad will be provided... Please note that only one writing pad will be provided to you.

8. An on-screen calculator will be provided...

9. The question palette displayed on the right side of the screen will show the status of each question with the help of one of the following symbols:

{/*
*/} {/*
S. No. Question Status Meaning
A You have not visited the question yet.
B You have visited the question but have not answered it.
C You have answered the question but have not flagged it as Marked for Review.
D You have not answered the question but have flagged it as Marked for Review.
E* You have answered the question as well as flagged it as Marked for Review.
*/}

*Answers to all questions flagged as â€˜Marked for Reviewâ€™ (Serial No. E) will be automatically considered as submitted for evaluation at the end of the time allotted for that section.

10. You can click on the "<" arrow which appears to the left of the question palette to collapse the question palette and maximize the window. To view the question palette again, you can click on the ">" which appears on the right side of the computer console.

11. To answer a question, you will need to do the following:

a. Click on the question number in the question palette to go to that question directly.

b. Select an answer for an MCQ by clicking on the radio button ( ) placed just before the choice.

For a Non-MCQ, enter only a whole number as the answer in the space provided on the screen using the on-screen keyboard. For example, if the correct answer to a Non-MCQ is 50, then enter ONLY 50 and NOT 50.0 or 050 etc.

c. Click on â€˜Save & Nextâ€™ to save your answer for the current question and then go to the next question.

Alternatively, you may click on â€˜Mark for Review & Nextâ€™ to save your answer for the current question and mark it for your review at any time before the completion of the section, and then move to the next question.

Caution: Your answer for the current question will not be saved, if you navigate directly to another question by clicking on a question number and not click â€˜Save & Nextâ€™ or â€˜Mark for Review & Nextâ€™ button.

d. You will be able to view all the questions of a section by clicking on the â€˜Question Paperâ€™ button. This feature is provided for you to see the entire question paper of a particular section.

12. Procedure for changing your response to a question:

a. To deselect your chosen answer, click on the question number on the question palette and click on the â€˜Clear Responseâ€™ button.

b. To change your chosen answer, click on the radio button corresponding to another option.

c. To save your changed answer, you must click on the â€˜Save & Nextâ€™ or â€˜Mark for Review & Nextâ€™ button.

13. Navigating through Sections:

a. The test has three sections administered in the following order: I. Verbal Ability and Reading Comprehension (VARC), II. Data Interpretation and Logical Reasoning (DILR), and III. Quantitative Ability (QA). The names of the three sections are displayed on the top bar of the screen. The section you are currently viewing is highlighted.

b. From any section, you will be able to move to the next section only after completing a minimum of 40 minutes, i.e., after the time allocated to that section for non-PwD candidates.

c. PwD candidates with blindness and low vision (or VI candidates) will have the screen magnification option enabled by default and will find two magnifying glass icons at the top of the screen. You can click on and click on to zoom out the question.

  1. 16x Pixel - Default View
  2. 21x Pixel - Level 1
  3. 24x Pixel - Level 2

Other Important Instructions

Subject Specific Instructions:

1. To login, enter your registration number and password following instructions provided to you by the invigilator.

2. Go through the various symbols used in the test and understand their meaning before you start the test.

3. The question paper consists of 3 (three) sections:

Section Test
I Verbal Ability and Reading Comprehension (VARC)
II Data Interpretation and Logical Reasoning (DILR)
III Quantitative Ability (QA)

4. The Data Interpretation and Logical Reasoning (DILR) section each problem is based on situations or scenarios and can have any number of sub questions. Similarly, for Reading Comprehension, each passage consists of a group of four questions.

5. For an MCQ, a candidate will be given 3 (three) marks for a correct answer, -1 (minus one) mark for a wrong answer and a 0 (zero) mark for an un-attempted question.

6. For a Non-MCQ, a candidate will be given 3 (three) marks for a correct answer, and a 0 (zero) mark for a wrong answer as well as for an un-attempted question. There will be no negative mark for a wrong answer in a Non-MCQ.

7. An MCQ will have choices out of which only one will be the correct answer. The computer allotted to you at the test centre runs on a specialized software that permits you to select only one answer for an MCQ. You will have to choose the correct answer by clicking on the radio button ( ) placed just before the option. For a Non-MCQ, you will have to enter only a whole number as the answer in the space provided on the screen using the on-screen keyboard.

8. Your answers will be updated and saved on a server periodically. The test will end automatically at the end of 120 minutes (or at the end of 160 minutes for PwD candidates). The time allotted for each section will be 40 minutes (or 53 minutes and 20 seconds for PwD candidates), after which you will not be allowed to go back to the earlier section(s).

Declaration by a Candidate:

  1. I have read and understood all the above instructions. I have also read and understood clearly the instructions given on the admit card and CAT website and shall follow the same. I declare that I am not wearing/carrying/in possession of any electronic communication gadgets or any prohibited material with me into the examination hall. I also understand that in case I violate any of these instructions, my candidature is liable to be cancelled and/or disciplinary action taken which may include debarring me from future tests and examinations.
  2. I confirm that at the start of the test, all computer hardware and software allotted to me are in working condition.
  3. I will not disclose, publish, reproduce, transmit, store, or facilitate transmission and storage of the contents of the CAT or any information therein in whole or part thereof in any form or by any means, verbal or written, electronically or mechanically for any purpose. I am aware that this shall be in violation of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 and/or the Copyright Act, 1957 and/or the Information Technology Act, 2000. I am aware that such actions and/or abetment thereof as aforementioned may constitute a cognizable offence punishable with imprisonment for a term up to three years and fine up to Rs. Two Lakhs.
) } export default Instruction;

start.sh.content:
#!/bin/bash

# Start backend in background
cd backend1
echo "Starting backend..."
NODE_ENV=development SKIP_SEED=1 node index.js &
BACKEND_PID=$!
cd ..

# Wait for backend to start
sleep 3

# Start frontend
cd Frontend1
echo "Starting frontend..."
PORT=5000 DANGEROUSLY_DISABLE_HOST_CHECK=true WDS_SOCKET_PORT=0 GENERATE_SOURCEMAP=false NODE_OPTIONS="--max-old-space-size=2048" npm start

# If frontend exits, kill backend
kill $BACKEND_PID 2>/dev/null
